articles.author: Geoff Graham
articles.description:
We‚Äôve started making a tradition of rounding up the latest front-end research at the end of each year. We did it in 2020 and again in 2021. Reports are released throughout the year by a bunch of different companies ‚Ä¶

articles.author: Geoff Graham
articles.description:
CSS Nesting is making the rounds yet again. Remember earlier this year when Adam and Mia put three syntax options up for a vote? Those results were tallied and it wasn‚Äôt even even close.
Now there‚Äôs another chance ‚Ä¶
Help choose the syntax for CSS Nesting originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Help choose the syntax for CSS Nesting

articles.author: Geoff Graham
articles.description:
Being able to quickly spin up a WordPress instance has been the strength of WordPress ever since its famous ‚Äúfive-minute install‚Äù. Upload a few files, configure a few settings, and you‚Äôre off.
The friction of uploading files has gotten ‚Ä¶
WordPress Playground: Running WordPress in the Browser originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: WordPress Playground: Running WordPress in the Browser

articles.author: Temani Afif
articles.description:
In this series, we‚Äôve been making image sliders with nothing but HTML and CSS. The idea is that we can use the same markup but different CSS to get wildly different results, no matter how many images we toss ‚Ä¶
CSS Infinite 3D Sliders originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: CSS Infinite 3D Sliders

articles.author: Geoff Graham
articles.description:
The CSS Working Group gave that a thumbs-up a couple weeks ago. The super-duper conceptual proposal being that we can animate or transition from, say, display: block to display: none.
It‚Äôs a bit of a brain-twister to reason ‚Ä¶
So, you‚Äôd like to animate the display property originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: So, you‚Äôd like to animate the display property

articles.author: Geoff Graham

Every so often, I find that the links I save to read later fall into natural groups or patterns that reveal common threads of interest. The past couple of weeks have produced a lot of thoughts about ChatGPT, an ‚Ä¶
Some Links on AI-Related Stuff originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.

articles.author: Geoff Graham
articles.description:
We‚Äôve got ourselves a real holiday treat! Join host Alex Trost from the Frontend Horse community for the Holiday Snowtacular 2022 this Friday, December 16.
There‚Äôs a lineup of 12 awesome speakers ‚Äî including Chris Coyier, Cassidy Williams, Kevin ‚Ä¶
Holiday Snowtacular 2022 originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.

articles.author: Dan Christofi
articles.description:
CSS Container Queries are still gaining traction and many of us are getting our hands wet with them, even if it‚Äôs for little experiments or whatnot. They‚Äôve got great, but not quite full, browser support ‚Äî enough to justify using ‚Ä¶
A Few Times Container Size Queries Would Have Helped Me Out originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.

articles.description:
Sara Soueidan with everything you need, from what screen reading options are out there all the way to setting up virtual machines for them, installing them, and confguring keyboard options. It‚Äôs truly a one-stop reference that pulls together disparate ‚Ä¶
Setting up a screen reader testing environment on your computer originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Setting up a screen reader testing environment on your computer

articles.author: Manoj Kumar
articles.description:
We‚Äôve accomplished a bunch of stuff in this series! We created a custom WordPress block that fetches data from an external API and renders it on the front end. Then we took that work and extended it so the data ‚Ä¶
Saving Settings for a Custom WordPress Block in the Block Editor originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Saving Settings for a Custom WordPress Block in the Block Editor

articles.author: Temani Afif
articles.description:
In the last article, we made a pretty cool little slider (or ‚Äúcarousel‚Äù if that‚Äôs what you prefer) that rotates in a circular direction. This time we are going to make one that flips through a stack of Polaroid ‚Ä¶
CSS Infinite Slider Flipping Through Polaroid Images originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: CSS Infinite Slider Flipping Through Polaroid Images

articles.author: Preethi
articles.description:
How often to do you reach for the CSS background-size property? If you‚Äôre like me ‚Äî and probably lots of other front-end folks ‚Äî then it‚Äôs usually when you background-size: cover an image to fill the space of an entire ‚Ä¶
Animated Background Stripes That Transition on Hover originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Animated Background Stripes That Transition on Hover

articles.author: Ganesh Dahal
articles.description:
The CSS box-shadow and outline properties gained theme.json support in WordPress 6.1. Let's look at a few examples of how it works in real themes, and what options we have to apply these styles to WordPress blocks and elements.
Adding Box Shadows to WordPress Blocks and Elements originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Adding Box Shadows to WordPress Blocks and Elements

articles.description:
Nothing but ear-to-ear smiles as I was watching this video from @quayjn on YouTube. (No actual name in the byline, though I think it‚Äôs Brian Katz if my paper trail is correct).
The best is this Pen you can ‚Ä¶
CSS is OK, I guess. originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: CSS is OK, I guess.

articles.author: Pieter De Decker
articles.description:
For years, a small pedantry war has been raging in our address bars. In one corner are brands like Google, Instagram, and Facebook. This group has chosen to redirect¬†example.com¬†to¬†www.example.com. In the opposite corner: ‚Ä¶
Does WWW still belong in URLs? originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Does WWW still belong in URLs?

articles.author: Temani Afif
articles.description:
Image sliders (also called carousels) are everywhere. There are a lot of CSS tricks to create the common slider where the images slide from left to right (or the opposite). It‚Äôs the same deal with the many JavaScript libraries out ‚Ä¶
CSS Infinite and Circular Rotating Image Slider originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: CSS Infinite and Circular Rotating Image Slider

articles.author: Geoff Graham
articles.description:
I wrote up some early thoughts on container style queries a little while back. It‚Äôs still early days. They‚Äôre already defined in the CSS Containment Module Level 1 specification (currently in Editor‚Äôs Draft status) but there‚Äôs still a couple of ‚Ä¶
Digging Deeper Into Container Style Queries originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Digging Deeper Into Container Style Queries

articles.author: Ganesh Dahal
articles.description:
One of the main goals of the WordPress Site Editor (and, yes, that is now the ‚Äúofficial‚Äù name) is to move basic block styling from CSS to structured JSON. JSON files are machine-readable, which makes it consumable by ‚Ä¶
Using The New Constrained Layout In WordPress Block Themes originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Using The New Constrained Layout In WordPress Block Themes

articles.author: Geoff Graham
articles.description:
I‚Äôm a sucker for anything about front-end job titles.
Anselm Hannemann:
CSS evolved and we‚Äôre beyond the point where everyone can just do it as a side interest. We all can learn it and build amazing stuff with it, 
‚Ä¶
More Than ‚ÄúSlapping Paint on a Website‚Äù originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: More Than ‚ÄúSlapping Paint on a Website‚Äù

articles.author: Daniel Schwarz
articles.description:
HTML lists are boring. They don‚Äôt do much, so we don‚Äôt really think about them despite how widely used they are. And we‚Äôre still able to do the same things we‚Äôve always done to customize them, like removing markers, reversing ‚Ä¶
Newer Things to Know About Good Ol‚Äô HTML Lists originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Newer Things to Know About Good Ol‚Äô HTML Lists

sources.title: Articles on Smashing Magazine ‚Äî For Web Designers And Developers

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Nicolas Hoffmann)
articles.description: You may have already heard of CSS logical properties or RTL adaptations but are still deciding whether to deploy them widely. To help raise your awareness of their possibilities, Nicolas Hoffmann shares his experience of how he and his team at Proton carried out a massive move from CSS logical props to production and how you can consider them from a different perspective in your very own projects.
articles.title: Deploying CSS Logical Properties On Web Apps

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Thomas Bohm)
articles.description: In this article, Thomas Bohm shares strategies and methods to tackle some common graphic communication problems and gives you insights into how to improve accessibility and usability and make your designs much better.
articles.title: Useful Accessibility And Usability Examples To Help Improve Your Designs

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Masha Shaposhnikova)
articles.description: In this article, Masha goes over five tips that make it easier to manage a design system while increasing its effectiveness. This short guide is aimed at smaller teams.
articles.title: Taking The Stress Out Of Design System Management

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Ashish Bogawat)
articles.description: In this article, Ashish Bogawat shares some of his favorite ways how to boost productivity and do things faster, better, and probably more fun by using efficient tools and workflows.
articles.title: Optimizing Your Design Workflow With Tools

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Suzanne Scacca)
articles.description: Concerns over online privacy and security are nothing new. In this article, Suzanne Scacca explores how the right CSV importer can help businesses better prioritize user security.
articles.title: How To Prioritize User Security When Collecting Offline Data

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Heather Burns)
articles.description: All of us want to create inclusive, safe, and privacy-aware digital experiences, but where to begin? Our brand new Smashing Book, ‚ÄúUnderstanding Privacy,‚Äù written by Heather Burns, can help you lay the ground for future developers, designers, and project managers to build a better web for tomorrow. [Jump to the details](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2022/12/understanding-privacy-new-smashing-book/#about-the-book) or [get the book right away](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/printed-books/understanding-privacy/).
articles.title: Understanding Privacy: Protect Your Users, Protect Yourself

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Adrian Bece)
articles.description: There is no universal solution for making every kind of table responsive and usable on smaller screens, so we have to rely on various patterns, which Adrian explains in this two-part series.
articles.title: Accessible Front-End Patterns For Responsive Tables (Part 2)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Keima Kai)
articles.description: In this article, Keima Kai provides a brief history of AI in web design, explores its current implications for creativity, and offers suggestions for how web designers can stay ahead of the curve.
articles.title: The Future Of Design: Human-Powered Or AI-Driven?

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Vitaly Friedman)
articles.description: ‚ÄúUnderstanding Privacy,‚Äù the new Smashing Book by Heather Burns, will help you create inclusive, safe and privacy-aware digital experiences. Print books are now shipping! [Jump to details](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2022/12/understanding-privacy-new-smashing-book/#about-the-book) and [get the book right away](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/printed-books/understanding-privacy/).
articles.title: It‚Äôs Here! ‚ÄúUnderstanding Privacy,‚Äù A New Smashing Book Is Shipping Now

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: Are you ready for the countdown to Christmas? This year, the web community was once again busy creating tech advent calendars jam-packed with fantastic content to sweeten your days. But which ones to follow? We help you find the right one, whether you‚Äôre a front-end dev, UX designer, or content strategist.
articles.title: Advent Calendars For Web Designers And Developers (2022 Edition)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Adrian Bece)
articles.description: There is no universal solution for making every kind of table responsive and usable on smaller screens, so we have to rely on various patterns, which Adrian explains in this two-part series.
articles.title: Accessible Front-End Patterns For Responsive Tables (Part 1)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Dan Donald)
articles.description: The world of design systems can be overwhelming sometimes. There‚Äôs a lot to take in when you get into that space! In this article, Dan Donald dives into a simple component and explores some issues, complexity, and power we can encounter.
articles.title: The Anatomy Of Themed Design System Components

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Fabienne Bielmann)
articles.description: Today, we‚Äôll take a look at the Sass function that does all the work for you ‚Äî with no media queries, no breakpoints, and no design jumps. In this article, Fabienne Bielmann explains what FabUnit stands for and why she decided to create her very own responsive magic formula.
articles.title: FabUnit: A Smart Way To Control And Synchronize Typo And Space

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: December is almost here, so why not spread some holiday love across your devices? We‚Äôve got some beautiful wallpapers to sweeten up the last days of the year.
articles.title: Endings And New Beginnings (December 2022 Desktop Wallpapers Edition)

Fun Fact: In a 2-socket server, you need 4 threads pegged at 100% to get 1% CPU utilization.

AMD's new SP5 socket, and HUGE new Epyc Genoa CPUs are crazy! Using Supermicro's servers, we set a bunch of World Records on a bunch of benchmarks. Intel is gonna be sweating, unless their upcoming Sapphire Rapids platform can magically compete. Intel's Raptor Lake CPUs might win against Ryzen in the mainstream, it's a whole different story in the datacenter.
